thread.title_full: BofA Said to Resign as Arch Coal Lender Agent Amid Creditor Feud - Bloomberg Business

author: Laura J Keller
title: BofA Said to Resign as Arch Coal Lender Agent Amid Creditor Feud
text:
Bank of America Corp. has resigned as the agent for Arch Coal Inc. lenders as some of them seek to block two debt exchanges intended to help the miner survive the commodities slump, said two people with knowledge of the matter.
Bank of America is removing itself from potential feuds involving Arch Coal, the senior lenders and lower-ranking bondholders, who would benefit by swapping their junior debt for secured obligations. A group of lenders claiming to own a majority of the miner’s $1.9 billion term loan sent a letter to Bank of America on Tuesday, asking the agent not to sign off on the debt exchange, Arch Coal said Wednesday in a regulatory filing. The lenders are concerned the swap will dilute their claims on the company’s assets, people with knowledge of the matter said last week.
With the bank’s resignation, the lenders will need to select a new administrative agent, said the people, who asked not to be named because the matter hasn’t been announced.
The exchanges are intended to ease the company’s $5.1 billion debt burden after a plunge in coal prices.
Bill Halldin, a spokesman for Charlotte, North Carolina-based Bank of America, declined to comment. Logan Bonacorsi, a spokeswoman for St. Louis-based Arch Coal, didn’t immediately respond to telephone and e-mail messages seeking comment.
